intro: Viguiera dentata var. helianthoides, commonly known as the Mexican sunflower, is a herbaceous perennial native to Mexico and the southwestern United States. It features showy, daisy-like yellow-orange flowers that bloom in late summer and early fall. The plant has hairy, gray-green leaves with a slightly rough texture, and it thrives in full sun with well-drained soil. It is drought-tolerant and often used in xeriscaping due to its hardiness and ornamental value. The species belongs to the Asteraceae family, which includes many other flowering plants with composite flower heads.
